descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses I have been one of your critics in that regard. Lately though I have tilted more pessimistic myself, especially after reading articles like this one. It offers false hope, describing a small portion of the problem. Much more than anthropogenic CO2, our ecosystem destruction is from overconsumption, toxic pollution, deforestation, infrastructure buildout, and overpopulation; its suggested solutions are necessary but far from sufficient.

#climatechange #climate

descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses
So humanity doesn't go extinct we need:
1. Replace GDP with better metric.
2. Less fragile technology.
3. Scenario planning on how population drops to a sustainable level.
4. Better strategic spatial planning to live in concordance with ecoregions.

descendants.content: @Starbrother @breadandcircuses I think people need to know that things are going to get bad because at the moment people arent equipped to deal with extreem weather or a local disaster ,local power outages,local water supply interruptions etc ,which are already happening ,every winter ,people have been without power for days and ditto water.People dont have sandbags etc to prevent houses flooding or have back up plans for where to go if they have to leave their homes due to floods or fires

account.note: I live in the north of Scotland ,I keep chickens and ducks ,this is a new profile for a new start ,but I am hoping to find many of my old Mastodon friends as time goes on

descendants.content: @Starbrother @breadandcircuses .People need to start signing up for weather and flood alerts and take storm warnings seriously and ensure their gardens and houses will be able to cope .And factor in things like flooding when they house hunt.One thing I didnt have until the past year or so was enough carriers to take all my birds to safety if there was a wildfire and we were almost in a postition of having to choose what lived and what died,luckily the fire didnt spread to us

descendants.content: @breadandcircuses wrote: "I'm sometimes accused of fear-mongering or doomism, focusing only on the bad news happening all around us and never pointing at the positives. Most of my regular followers will know that's not really true, that I often highlight articles about the kinds of transformative changes that if made would carry us into a cleaner, safer, happier future." descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses There's a big difference between:

- Climate change is going to be catastrophic. We're not even close to doing enough to reduce emissions. There's no way we can avert disaster.

... and ...

- Climate change is going to be catastrophic. We're not even close to doing enough to reduce emissions. It's very difficult to see a way out, but we have to try.

The former is doomerism, the latter is (in my view) realism.

account.note:
Political Science postdoc researcher at Victoria University of Wellington (New Zealand). My research focusses on politics of climate change, and on comparative politics in general.

I've been coding most of my life, and use FOSS whenever possible.

#PoliticalScience #PoliSci #Academia #ClimateChange #OpenScience

descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses In my work on climate opinion, I've seen a gradual acceptance by the public - not just of the existence and seriousness of climate change - but of the urgent need to act now.

It's changing slowly (too slowly), but it is changing.

descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses
>I'm sometimes accused of fear-mongering or doomism, focusing only on the bad news happening all around us and never pointing at the positives

---

It's endlessly fascinating to me that people can be so self deceptive. It does go along way to explaining some of this though I guess

People can look at the Keeling Curve, extinction rates, pollution levels and the everday habits of billions etc and make outlandish statements like "good news, we put solar panels on car park roofs" or "voters say they want action on climate change " etc and frame this as "good news". It's not even like they're clinging to a life vest in a stormy ocean, they're literally clinging to a dead weight, going down holding their breath and claiming it's good news.

This nonsense is so ubiqutuos that it itself is the doomism that's more difficult to understand then the outright stupidity that is science denial.

Where is the massive push back against Taylor Swift concerts, Olympic Games, flying for holidays etal The people doing that are the same ones allowing billionares to desecrate the planet by voting for politcans who enable it and calling that good news, those behaviours are the very real ones causing so much "doom."

-----

>Most of my regular followers will know that's not really true

Indeed.

>"I see no way out of revolutionary changes to how we live today .... it is too late for non-radical futures" - Professor Kevin Anderson

https://social.rebellion.global/@ScientistRebellion/110235597189756736

descendants.content:
@largess @breadandcircuses

What I'm finding hard to deal with at the moment is that it's increasingly those who claim to be on the "Left" (really, they're Centre Right) that are decrying those sounding the alarm about fascism, climate and ecological breakdown etc.
Somebody on here the other day was claiming environmentalists and those on the "far Left", whatever that means, are all Russian bots seeking to undermine Kamala Harris. I don't even know how to interact with that level of stupidity. My brain just tends to shut down and I think "f*ck it" to myself, and don't even bothering engaging.
Part of it, I appreciate, is that many people simply cannot cognitively process the idea that 2C warming is unavoidably locked in and we're in a catastrophic situation

descendants.content:
@Shivviness @largess @breadandcircuses we are indeed tipping in #weird waters, thanks to years of cut in #education, #tech exploding, neo-liberalism paving the way to oligarchy, among other things.

We’ve been through this before. Hopefully, we’ll succeed yet again at creating civilized discourse, honorable communities and a sense of peace we haven’t seen in a few decades.

@breadandcircuses

I shared a peer-reviewed paper by James Hansen on the Climate subReddit a few days ago, because there was a technical aspect of it that I was unclear on. The moderator removed it and told me not to post "collapse nonsense" on his subReddit.
Hansen has said categorically that 2C warming is locked in.
Here is a Guardian article spelling out that climate scientists expect us to blow past 2.5C at the rate we're going.
The elites think they'll be safe in their bunkers and gated communities. They won't.
The concierge class of professionals who serve the elites also think they'll be safe. Again, they will perish along with the rest of us.
Neurotypical humans generally in my experience really will resist changes to the societal status quo fiercely, and simply can't mentally grasp the idea that we're looking at the collapse of everything. They pour scorn on those sounding the alarm and sink into the mistaken, albeit comfortable belief think they'll always be able to drive to a well-stocked supermarket and buy whatever they need

https://www.theguardian.com/environment/article/2024/may/08/world-scientists-climate-failure-survey-global-temperature
